Posts.Content: Hello everyone I was diagnosed 8 weeks ago with a Grade 2 lobular tumour in my right breast under my nipple. It was the location that caught my attention as my nipple had become slightly inverted.  Two weeks ago I had my nipple, areola and lump removed from my breast together with a sentinel node biopsy.  The wounds are healing really well. Today I received the results which were the best results I could have hoped for, all the tumour has been removed from breast with a wide local excision and the four nodes that were removed were all negative which is brilliant news.  I asked if there is any merit in having an oncotype test which would be specific to me and would maybe help me decide if it would be prudent to have chemotherapy to help reduce the risk of recurrence.  I was informed that my 'score' is too low and I do not qualify for an oncotype test on NHS due to cost.  I do understand that there isn't a bottomless pot of money and I consider have been given excellent treatment and care treatment throughout this ordeal. I am prepared to pay for this test myself, and my consultant is OK with this.  I really do not want to have chemo and My breast care nurse has advised of all the problems that can arise having the treatment and has implied that I should really just get on with my life having had such a positive result.  I don't disagree and I know that only I can make the decision about what to do but I would very much welcome anyone's views on this to put into my 'melting pot'.   Many thanks.

Posts.Content: Hey Caz90 Thanks for your reply. The Onchotype test is available on NHS providing our score is above a certain number. The tool to measure this is called the Nottingham Prognostic Index I believe, my  results from my pathology report were used to calculate whether there would be any merit in me having the test done to obtain an indication as to  likely recurrence, because my results scored too low  by NHS guidelines ie. Nottingham Prognostic Index , I am not eligible for the Onchotype test on the NHS. I do appreciate the NHS does not have a bottomless pit of monies and a line has to be drawn somewhere.  So with the help of my family and thus forum I have decided to accept my all clear results as given by these very clever teams of surgeons and as recommended , get on with my life.        Hopefully I have helped and not totally confused by my probable poor explanation .  Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Hello there ! One year ago I had wide local excision surgery to remove my Grade 2 tumour followed by radiotherapy. Today I collected the results for a mamogram that I had last week and to have a clinical assessment . Thankfully the mamogram did not show any abnormalities and neither did my clinical assessment carried out by a doctor within the breast care team. I am relieved at  these findings. I feel frustrated with myself as I am not as elated by these results and I feel I should be. The reason , I think, is because when I had my mamogram a year ago with the tumour in situ , it did not show up, it was only when I had an ultra sound scan that it became evident . I was told that one of the reasons the tumour was not apparent on the mamogram was because it was a lobular cancer and harder for a mamogram to detect.  Today I asked to have an ultra sound scan in view of my experience a year ago and was informed that a scan could still not be entirely conclusive . ??  If I wanted further reassurance I should persue an MRI scan of the breast area privately , which could be more accurate. I do understand and appreciate that I would need to pay for this . My husband says that he thinks that if it were him he would accept the results I have been given and get on with living my life. I understand what he is saying , however I can't help wondering if I should have an MRI scan for what I hope would provide reassurance at this moment in time ? Am I overthinking this ??? Any advice , guidance opinions and views would be gratefully received. thank you . Ludo xxx

Posts.Content: Following surgery last November to remove a Grade 2 lobular tumour and removal of my nipple. I had appointment on Wednesday with a doctor as part of my 6 monthly check.  I mentioned the constant mild pain I've been experiencing in my breast for the past 3 weeks  . He examined me and couldn't feel anything untoward and suggested it could possibly as a result of the radiotherapy and to take some anti inflammatory meds ie Ibuprofen for five days and if not any better I should have a bone scan to see if any cancer may have spread to my bones. Does this seem a drastic move? More radiation which Would only identify cancer in my bones and not tissue.  Would an MRI scan be more suitable, accurate and less invasive? Has anyone else experienced this kind of pain post rad treatment ? Confused and concerned . Thanks . Ludo X
